item.title: Make a website using R and Github pages
item.description:
Why make a website using R studio and github pages?

You're an R user who is looking to make a professional webpage that:

  1. Takes advantage of Hugo website themes
  2. Doesn't require learning html or java
  3. Can be hosted on a free domain (Github Pages)

Note: This tutorial assumes that you have basic proficiency using Github, R studio, and github repositories with R projects. If you aren't comfortable with this yet, start here instead.

*Disclaimer: This is meant to be a quick step-by-step guide to generate a webpage from beginning to end. For more a more extensive guide on all things related to using blogdown, see the official Blogdown documentation .

Part 1: Build your website

1.1 Choose a theme for your website

  • Hugo has a wide array of website themes, which can be found here.
  • Themes dictate both the aethetics and the format of a website.
  • Choose wisely. Once you start with a certain theme, it's hard to switch themes later.

1.2 Use blogdown to generate a website template

  • Once you've chosen a theme, click “Homepage” on the theme website, which leads you to the owner's github repository for the theme. We will use this github project (e.g. “user/themename”) as input to the blogdown::new_website function. Step by step instructions below:

  • in R studio, install the blogdown package and load the library.
    install.packages(‘blogdown’) install.packages(‘hugo’) library(blogdown)

  • Make a brand new R project in a new directory
    File –> New Project –> New directory –> choose location

  • Generate a website from the theme template in your R Project.
    blogdown::new_website(theme = “user/themename”)

1.3 Edit content on your website

Every theme has a slightly different setup, but we will walk through the basic overview. You can also read the theme documentation for more details on your chosen theme.

  • Config and menu files contain the backbone structure of your website. Config files designate the url, theme, and title of your website. Menu files designate the “widgets” or components of your website (which varies by theme). Disclaimer: depending on the theme, these files may be in the main directory or different locations (e.g. in the “data” or “config” folders) and might end with either “.toml” or “.yml”.
  • Content: This is where most of your editing will take place. The organization of this folder will vary depending on your chosen theme, and the files here should coincide with your menu.
  • Static: This is the storage location for any static files that you add to your website. For example, you can add PDF files or images that you link in the content.
  • Themes: This stores the necessary code to build the website using your chosen theme. Do not edit!
  • Public: Contains the live website, built from the contents and configurations. Do not edit!

It will take some trial-and-error to figure out how changes in these files correspond to changes in the website. Try making a simple change first, like changing the title of your webpage in the config file, annd see how it changes your webpage. The next step describes how to preview your site.

1.4 Preview your website as you make changes

  • You can see changes live as you save them by rendering the site
    blogdown::serve_site()
  • The webpage will automatically display in the viewer panel of R studio.
  • To see the webpage preview in full size, click open in a new window (on the top left of the Viewer panel) to open it in your browser.

Do I need to run serve_site() after every change I make?
It depends. After running it once, the webpage preview will automatically refresh after each time you save changes to existing files, but if you remove or add new widgets, you will need to re-run the command to view those structural changes.

Part 2: Link the website to github

Before we start, it's important to explain that there will be 2 separate github repositories for this website. This is because hugo (and many website platforms) separate editable content from your live website content (‘public’ folder).
1. webpage: This repository will contain the editable contents of your website, which you already generated in step 1.
2. username.github.io: This repository will be a submodule of the ‘webpage’ repository. It contains the ‘public’ folder of your website, and is used to generate your live website on github pages.

2.1 Make a ‘webpage’ repository

  • make a new repository on github, and call it ‘webpage’ or whatever you'd like to call your main website repo. Don't add anything to the repository yet!
  • Copy the ‘clone’ link for your new repository.
  • Open R studio and click File –> New Project.
  • Choose ‘from version control’ and ‘Github’ in the project options.
  • Create your R project using the copied repository link.
  • Then copy the entire contents of your Hugo website into the new R project directory & close your R project.

2.2 Make the ‘username.github.io’ repository and add it as a submodule.

  • Make a new repository on github called username.github.io. Github pages will automatically generate a webpage from any repository with this specific name, so unfortunately you cannot be creative here!
  • Open terminal and navigate to your webpage directory on your local machine:
    cd /your-local-directories/webpage/
  • Delete your public repository: rm -rf public
  • Now we are going to add our ‘username.github.io’ repository as a submodule of the ‘webpage’ repository: submodule add -b master https://github.com/username/username.github.io.git public
  • Next time we serve the site, the ‘username.github.io.git’ repository will contain the contents of the ‘public’ directory.

2.3 Set your website html address

  • Open the config.toml file in the home directory of your webpage_hugo R project.
  • Replace the baseURL https://example.com with your github page domain: https://username.github.io
  • Save the changes to the config.toml file.

For additional information and trouble-shooting, see the related Hugo documentation for hosting websites on github pages.

Part 3: Serve website

3.1 Edit content on your webpage

  • Open your ‘webpage’ R project to continue editing content on your website.
  • Re-generate the public folder with updated content: blogdown::serve_site()

3.2 Deploy your changes to the live website

  • Here, we are going to push the changes to the ‘public’ directory to our ‘username.github.io’ repository. This step has to be done in terminal, not R studio.
  • In terminal, navigate to the public folder of the ‘webpage’ directory.
    cd webpage/public
  • Add, commit and push your changes with the following lines of code:
    git add .
    git commit -m “my message here”
    git push origin master
  • Check your live website updates at username.github.io

3.3 Track your content changes to the website repository

  • Here, we are going to push the changes of the ‘webpage’ directory to the ‘webpage’ repository. I prefer to do this using R studio.
  • Exclude the ‘public’ folder from being tracked by adding this line to your .gitignore file: public/.
  • Make sure you commit & push the updated .gitignore file too.

You now have a functioning website built with github, R and hugo!

item.title: Building a Website with Blogdown, Hugo and Github Pages
item.description:
A few months ago, I attended an R ladies NYC workshop on creating websites with Blogdown with Hugo themes. For the R user who is looking to generate their own webpage - look no further! The Blogdown R package has powerful capabilities without needing to learn html or java, and Hugo has a seemingly endless choice of beautiful website themes. There are many resources available, but it's easy to get bogged down in the details when you're just getting started.

Here, I am going to walk through a step-by-step guide to generate a webpage from beginning to end, using Blogdown, Hugo and Github pages.

Why use Github pages to deploy the website? First, it's free - every github user has a free domain to use. Second, it's easily linked to your github profile. Third, it really encourages you to version control your website!

Part 1: Build your website

Choose a theme for your website

Hugo has a wide array of website themes, which can be found here. Themes dictate both the aethetics and the format of a website. Choose wisely - once you start with a certain theme, it's hard to switch themes later.

After you've chosen a theme, click “Homepage” on the theme website, which leads you to the owner's github repository for the theme. We will use this github project (e.g. “user/themename”) as input to the blogdown::new_website function.

Use blogdown to generate a website template

Now we're ready to start working with blogdown. Start a new R project, and then generate a new blogdown website using your chosen theme.

install.packages('blogdown')
install.packages('hugo')
library(blogdown)
blogdown::new_website(theme = "user/themename")

Edit content on your website

Every theme has a slightly different setup, but we will walk through the basic overview. I also recommend reading the theme documentation for more details.

  • Config and menu files: Contain the backbone structure of your website. Config files designate the url, theme, and title of your website. Menu files designate the “widgets” or components of your website (which varies by theme). Disclaimer: depending on the theme, these files may be in the main directory or different locations (e.g. in the “data” or “config” folders) and might end with either “.toml” or “.yml”.
  • Content: Where most of your editing will take place. The organization of this folder will vary depending on your chosen theme, and the files here should coincide with your menu.
  • Static: The storage location for any static files that you add to your website. For example, you can add PDF files or images that you link in the content.
  • Themes: Stores the necessary code to build the website using your chosen theme. Do not edit!
  • Public: Contains the live website, built from the contents and configurations. Do not edit!

Preview your changes

Blogdown also makes it really easy to preview changes. With this commmand, the webpage will display in the viewer panel and can be expanded to full view, just like any other html document.

blogdown::serve_site()

There is some trial-and-error to figure out how changes in the content files correspond to changes in the website. Try making a simple change first, like changing the title of your webpage in the config file, and see how it changes your webpage.

Do I need to run serve_site() after every change I make?
It depends. After running it once, the webpage preview will automatically refresh after each time you save changes to existing files, but if you remove or add new widgets, you will need to re-run the command to view those structural changes.

Part 2: Link the website to Github & Github pages

Make a ‘webpage’ repository

Websites change, and websites also break… but this all becomes much more manageable with version control! First, you want to make a new github repository, and link it to a new R project.

Not familiar with linking github and R? When making a new new R project, choose the option ‘from version control’, then ‘Github’. On the next page, add the link to your git repository.

The ‘public’ folder should not be added to this repository! An easy way to deal with this is to add the public directory to your .gitignore file.

When you're happy with the content of your webpage, add, commit and push the website content to the ‘webpage’ repository.

Make a ‘github pages’ repository

Hugo, like many other website platforms, separates the editable content of your website from the live website content, also commonly referred to as the “public” content. To deploy the website, we will sync the “public” folder to Github pages.

First, make a new repository on github called username.github.io. Github pages will automatically generate a webpage from any repository with this specific name, so unfortunately you cannot be creative here. Then, add the ‘username.github.io’ repository as a submodule of the ‘webpage’ repository.

For these few lines of code, we need to excute git commands in terminal, outside of R studio.

cd /path-to-webpage/** 
rm -rf public
submodule add -b master https://github.com/username/username.github.io.git public

This enables the ‘username.github.io.git’ repository to contain only the ‘public’ directory of your website.

Finally, update the website address in the config.toml file. Simply replace “baseURL” with your github pages url (https://username.github.io).

Deploy your changes to the live website

When you're ready to make your webpage live, the process is pretty painless. Simply add, commit and push your public website content to the github pages repsitory, and the webpage will automatically update at https://username.github.io.

cd webpage/public
git add . 
git commit -m "my message here"
git push origin master

You now have a functioning website built with github, R and hugo!

Further reading

  • For additional information and trouble-shooting, see the related Hugo documentation for hosting websites on github pages.

  • For an excellent resource on using github with R, check out this excellent resource: Happy Git with R .

  • For more blogdown details, far beyond the scope covered here: Blogdown documentation

item.title: Data Dashboard
item.description:
During my post-doctoral fellowship at NYU Langone Health, I worked on a research project that assessed the impact of the covid-19 pandemic on maternal health and well-being. New and expecting mothers shared their experiences during the covid-19 pandemic and how they are coping with those challenges. These data were collected via remote surveys from women in the NYC metropolitan area from April - July 2020.

In order to facilitate rapid dissemination of our research relating to Covid-19, I used R shiny to develop an interactive data dashboard that displays key findings from this study. We show how the covid-19 pandemic has impacted various aspects of women's lives, from major changes to perinatal healthcare, to their concerns about disruptions to social, economic, and family life.

item.title: Predicting age from brain imaging data
Early experience and brain development
item.description:
PhD Thesis Research

In my graduate research, I studied the role of early experiences on brain maturation and later mental health risk. My dissertation research used structural MRI to identify how patterns of brain development differed following exposure to early adversity. I focused on brain regions that are important for processing emotions (amygdala and hippocampus) and implicated in mental health risk. My research showed that exposure to early adversity was linked to differences in the size and growth of these brain regions across childhood and adolescence. Importantly, these neurobiological changes were also associated with increased anxiety and depressive symptoms. These findings contribute to the body of knowledge idenifying how early adverse experiences can ‘get under the skin’ to influence long-term health outcomes.

These findings are presented in a pre-print manuscript currently under review.

This work was conducted in the Developmental Affective Neuroscience Lab , Department of Psychology, Columbia University.

item.title: Three myths about concussions
item.description:
Since that first accident 18 months ago, I’ve had two more crashes, and unfortunately, two more concussions. I’ll save those stories for another time. But through all of these experiences, I learned about the common misconceptions about head injury, helmets, and concussion severity.

1. You didn’t lose consciousness!

When describing my crash, the first question everyone asked me was the same: did you lose consciousness? This common assumption – that head injuries are only serious if you lose consciousness – is largely false. Loss of consciousness only occurs in about 10% of head injuries, and research is inconclusive about whether loss of consciousness actually predicts concussion severity or recovery time. In reality, there are several other risk factors that are more important, and often over-looked. For example, even though men are twice as likely to have a head injury, women are much more likely to suffer from concussions. Likewise, prior history of head injury, and prior mental health history also influence how quickly an individual might recover from a head injury.

2. Your helmet didn’t break!

One common misconception, which is prevalent both in the cycling community and the emergency room, is that a head injury doesn’t need to be taken seriously if you were wearing your helmet, especially if the helmet didn’t break. But the reality is that industry standards only require that a cycling helmet protects against serious traumatic brain injury, like a skull fracture. Your helmet will likely save your life, but it won’t prevent a concussion. Only recently have new helmet technologies been developed to protect against concussions, by trying to minimize the rotational forces that occur when your head makes impact. However, these helmets are very new, and proprietary, with very little objective research (i.e. not funded by the company) that have tested their efficacy in the real world.

3. Your CT scan was negative!

The most common test performed following a head injury is a CT scan, which is used to diagnose acute problems like intracranial bleeding that require urgent medical attention. If your doctor says the CT scan is clear, that means your helmet did its job – it prevented a life-threatening situation. However, you may still have a concussion. There are no biological or imaging tests that can diagnose a concussion. The symptoms are largely invisible, and can only be diagnosed from the patient’s own self-report (e.g. feeling foggy, irritable, dizzy, or having difficulty concentrating). Importantly, these symptoms may not emerge until hours or days after you’ve left the emergency room. That’s why follow-up evaluations are recommended for anyone who sustains a head injury - even if you are feeling fine in the initial few days afterward.

Concussion Resources:

  • Concussion signs and symptoms from the CDC

  • Concussion Do's and Don'ts

  • Concussion management from USA Cycling

  • Medicine of Cycling Traumatic Brain Injury Flow Chart

item.title: Positive valence bias and parent-child security moderate the effect of institutional care on internalizing symptoms
Neurobiological programming of early life stress: Functional development of amygdala-prefrontal circuitry and vulnerability for stress-related psychopathology
Forecasting tool for longitudinal studies
item.description:
Interactive web application for developmental researchers

In developmental psychology, it's common to collect data from the same participants over time to measure developmental milestones of interest. These longitudinal studies involve research visits at multiple time points, presenting challenges for project management across long timescales. The optimal study design to answer a given research question must be balanced with logistical constraints of the research team, and the time burden placed on participating families.

Many variables are considered when designing a longitudinal study:

  • total number of participants (50, or 500?)
  • total duration of the study (e.g. 6 months or 6 years?)
  • target age of participants at each visit (newborn, 12 months, 5 years?)
  • target populations of interest (e.g. low vs. high SES?)

I developed an interactive tool to facilitate study planning for longitudinal research studies. It's specifically geared towards research groups with existing pregnancy cohorts that plan to conduct infant follow-up assessments (e.g. newborn, 6-month and 12-month). Given how rapidly infants reach developmental milestones, the timing of study assessments is extremely important.

The web application, developed with R shiny, allows the researcher to provide their own source data for their unique study cohort, and see how study decisions impact the long-term study forecast. The source data includes birth dates (or due dates), and any enrichment variables relevant to that cohort (e.g. income brackets). The user can then interactively change the total number of participants to be included, time intervals between visits, target age of participants at each visit, and the total duration of the study. The output provides summary metrics, with figures to vizualize the projected volume of study visits over time. Once the study design has been selected, the output tables can then be used by project managers to effectively plan study operations and study budgets on a weekly basis.

This work was done during my Post-doctoral fellowship at NYU Langone Health.

item.title: My (first) concussion story
item.description:
This post is the first of a series of posts on concussions and recovery.

It was my first full season of racing, and after a couple of near-misses on the Cat 4/5 podium, it was my last chance to show off my new-found love for racing criteriums. Bored of Central Park by this late in the season, I opted to go north on the west side bike path to the less traveled Fort Tryon Park in Inwood. I did a short workout, easy openers to prep my legs for the next day’s race: Fort Lee Crit. The riding conditions were great - it had rained overnight, but the sun was out and it was such a nice day that it was hard to resist the urge to join my friends for a long ride across the GW bridge. But with my goal set on having fresh legs for the next day, I started to make my way home, thinking that I was safer on the bike path than on the roads in Washington Heights.

If you ever ride north of 155th St, you’ll know the bridge: the broken, run-down, wooden bridge that used to be adorned with gaping holes and giant orange cones, which crosses over the abandoned train tracks. Having ridden across a dozen times by now, I didn’t think twice as I coasted down the hill southbound, and rode onto the bridge at around 10 mph. As I carefully avoided the gaping wooden holes and orange cones, my front tire wedged between 2 planks of wet, rotten, slippery wood. I lost control of my bike, and fell toward my left side, with the side of my head being the first point of contact. Dazed, but having not lost consciousness, I lied there stunned in the middle of the bridge. A few runners who had witnessed the incident stopped to ask me if I was ok. I wasn’t sure. I was talking normally and could even get up to walk my bike to the side of the path, but they still wanted to call 911. In the 30 minutes that we waited for the ambulance, two more cyclists wiped out at the same spot on the bridge.

When I was finally at the ER, the physician’s assistant who evaluated me was not concerned about my head injury. My helmet didn’t crack. I didn’t lose consciousness. My pupils weren’t dilated, and I wasn’t vomiting, nauseous, or dizzy. I told her I had a big race the next day, and I was anxious to hear the answer: could I race? Would it be safe? She merely advised me to see how I felt. As a determined athlete, her nonchalance seemed like a green light that I was good to go. She handed me a pamphlet on how to treat road rash, and I was discharged.

The most important thing that this doctor did not tell me is that concussion symptoms might not appear right away. In fact, they may not appear for hours or days, but could persist for weeks or months.

After taking it easy the rest of the day, I woke up the next morning feeling great and ready to race. I practiced the course so much, I knew it by heart - especially the punchy hill that dropped half the field on the first lap. In the end, I got 4th place, again, but I didn’t care - I was thrilled that my crash hadn’t held me back. I was so elated on my post-race high that I did a social ride up River Road with my friends afterwards, and even PRed on Alpine! But after lunch, I was so tired that I could hardly make my way back down 9W. My boyfriend, who loves to chase after random wheels, had left me in the dust. I looked at the low numbers on my power meter and thought, damn I am tired. But that was normal after a bike race, right?

During the next few days, things were as normal as they could be. Except, when I sat at my computer, I couldn’t keep my head up or my eyes open. With my stubborn PhD student work ethic, I tried to drag myself through the rest of the week, buying extra afternoon coffees, eager to get to the weekend stage race I had planned. Other than some mild neck whiplash and fatigue, I seemed fine. But by the weekend, I started getting head fog and dizziness on the bike. I decided I shouldn’t race, so I cheered my teammates from the sidelines. When I returned to the city on Monday, more than a week after my crash, it got worse. Daily activities, like riding the subway or working on the computer, would trigger a headache.

My primary care doctor told me to take time off from school and recommended I see a concussion specialist. Thanks to the over-burdened healthcare system in NYC, the next available appointment wasn’t for 4 weeks. I spent the next month trying to manage my symptoms on my own. Not wanting to relent on my summer plans, I attempted a beach vacation, a bachelorette party, and an international conference, all while trying to avoid my headache triggers: computer screens, direct sunlight, loud noise, heat, and alcohol. The subway was a nightmare, florescent lights were terrible, and bars were even worse. I would sleep 10+ hours a night, and took naps whenever I could. I wouldn’t go anywhere without Excedrin, crime podcasts, and my noise-cancelling headphones.

By the time I had my specialist appointment a month later, my day-to-day symptoms had started to improve, but the evaluation revealed more symptoms that I had hardly noticed amid the blinding headaches. Neuropsychology testing showed small deficits in my working memory and balance. I learned that my dizziness on the bike was from the damage to my inner ear from the crash. I started vestibular physical therapy, where I did balance exercises, and occupational therapy, where they gave me strategies to get through my work at the computer.

There is no one-size fits-all prognosis for how bad your symptoms will be after a concussion, or how quickly you’ll get better. While friends of mine have recovered from their bike-related head injuries in a few days, it took me almost 3 months to fully recover. I stayed on the indoor trainer for weeks until I was finally ready to bike outside again. Eventually, and very slowly, I got better, and I learned a lot about concussions in the process. The goal of this blog series is to help educate other cyclists about concussions, and the common misconceptions surrounding them.

Concussion Resources:

  • Concussion signs and symptoms from the CDC

  • Concussion Do's and Don'ts

  • Concussion management USA Cycling
